features: Theogony (generation of gods from primordial pair)
Anthropogony (creation of humanity from divine blood)
Cosmic order as ongoing struggle against chaos
description: The Enuma Elish, 'When on High,' is the Babylonian creation epic preserved on seven cuneiform tablets dating to approximately 1100 BCE, though the mythology likely predates the text by centuries. This foundational narrative describes how the cosmos emerged from the primordial mingling of fresh water (Apsu) and salt water (Tiamat), and how the young champion god Marduk defeated the chaos dragon Tiamat in cosmic battle. From Tiamat's divided corpse, Marduk fashioned the heavens and earth; from the blood of her consort Kingu, he created humanity to serve the gods and relieve them of labor. The epic served both cosmological and political purposes - recited annually at the Akitu (New Year) festival in Babylon, it legitimated Marduk's supremacy over older Sumerian deities and, by extension, Babylon's hegemony over Mesopotamia. The Enuma Elish profoundly influenced later creation narratives, including biblical Genesis, through its imagery of primordial waters, divine speech creating order, and separation of heaven from earth. Its central theme - that cosmic order must be violently wrested from chaos and constantly defended through ritual - shaped Mesopotamian religion for over a millennium.

sections.origins: The Enuma Elish was composed in its canonical form around 1100 BCE, during the reign of Nebuchadnezzar I, though elements of the mythology are much older. The epic represents a systematic theologizing of earlier Sumerian creation traditions, adapted to elevate Marduk - the patron god of Babylon - to supremacy over the older Sumerian pantheon. This reflects Babylon's political rise to power in Mesopotamia. The epic draws on older traditions: Ea's defeat of Apsu parallels earlier Sumerian myths, and the combat motif has roots in Syrian and Hurrian storm god mythology.
sections.attributes: The Enuma Elish's distinctive attributes include its combat cosmogony (creation through divine battle), its seven-tablet structure (paralleling the seven days of later creation narratives), and its integration of cosmology with political theology. The epic explains not only how the world came to be but why Marduk deserves worship and why Babylon deserves to rule. Its cosmic structure - heaven stretched above like a tent, earth floating on the underground waters - reflects Mesopotamian observations of their flat, irrigated landscape surrounded by water.
sections.significance: The Enuma Elish is among the most important religious texts of the ancient world. Its annual recitation at the Akitu New Year festival ritually renewed the cosmos by reenacting Marduk's victory over chaos. The epic profoundly influenced later Near Eastern religions: the Hebrew Bible's Genesis contains clear echoes (tehom/Tiamat, creation by divine speech, separation of waters, human creation from earth), though transformed to express monotheistic theology. The epic's theme of order requiring constant defense against chaos remains a powerful paradigm for understanding the Mesopotamian worldview and continues to influence comparative mythology and religious studies.
